prompt.description: Please describe what you know about the functionality of the Open Response Assessment tool (the one you are currently using to write this essay). Be as complete as you can in 300 words or less.
You can use up to 150 additional words to describe interesting uses you've seen for Open Response Assessments.

criterion.name: Ideas
criterion.label: Functionality
criterion.prompt: Which of the following tasks were described?

option.name: Poor
option.label: Peer-, self-, and staff-grading
option.explanation: All three options were covered, and maybe even the Training step that most people skip because it's a bit of a pain for the learners.

option.name: Fair
option.label: Just one or two of the above
option.explanation: Peer grading, self-grading, OR staff-grading, but not all three.

option.name: Good
option.label: None of the above
option.explanation: No mention of any of these at all, strangely.

option.name: Poor
option.label: Yes with...
option.explanation: ...with comments on awarding different numbers of points for different categories

criterion.label: Interaction
criterion.prompt: How about the way learners can see and comment on each others' work in a way that's more than just a numerical grade but more structured than freeform responses?

option.label: Didn't think of that...
option.explanation: ...but I'd like to make sure this person gets points anyway.

criterion.label: Grade disputes
criterion.prompt: Did they address what happens if someone's grade is wrong?

option.label: Yes, they talked about grade overrides
Come on, trust your learners.
option.explanation: People generally do take these things seriously, you know.

criterion.label: Multiple Grading Stages
criterion.prompt: Did the writer perhaps discuss how awkward it can be to write rubrics that work for both self-grading and peer grading at the same time without sounding sort of odd?

option.label: Yes, I rather noticed that just now.
You just do your best and move on, I suppose.
option.explanation: Or you could just do one grading stage.

criterion.label: Other activities
criterion.prompt: Did the person mention any other uses for Open Response Assessments? What about using a very simple self-grading rubric for journaling activities that allow learners to return and see what they've written later on?

option.label: I think I'm getting tired of grading at this point.
option.explanation: Maybe we could wrap this up.

rubric.feedbackprompt: (Optional) What misconceptions or serious oversights did you see in this person's response? Is there anything that you want to point out to make sure they understand it?
rubric.feedback_default_text: Dear wonderful colleague, did you know...
